abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Water Supply
            Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The project largely
            achieved its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and the performance of the Bank was highly satisfactory
            while the Borrower's was satisfactory. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, the sector
            reorganization that entailed the establishment of autonomous
            agencies and private sector participation served to
            significantly improve sector performance. Second, universal
            improvements in efficiency should not be taken for granted,
            even in a privately operated system. Third, when a lease
            contract is being designed, short-term and long-term
            incentive structures should be carefully created to meet
            precisely articulated objectives to maximize the efficiency
            of the private sector operations. Fourth, in the interest of
            consumer protection, a strong regulatory and oversight
            function is very important to control private sector
            operations. Finally, to increase transparency in operations
            when a private operator functions as a system operator and
            construction contractor, separate financial statements of
            its different functions are highly recommended.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Second Water
            Supply Project is to create a legal, institutional,
            technical, and financial framework which will constitute the
            basis for a sound take-off and development of the sector.
            The project is composed of the following components : (i) a
            management support program to the National Water Authority
            (SONEG) including technical assistance, training and
            equipment; (ii) the rehabilitation of sector operations;
            (iii) a rehabilitation program of the existing facilities
            including the supply of equipment for the domestic plants,
            small diameter pipes and water meters; and (iv) the
            expansion of the Conakry water supply system including the
            supply and installation of material and equipment. Further
            to this, the project will also supply consultants'
            services for the preparation of urban and water supply
            studies in secondary centers, and a training program for the
            National Water Company's (DGE) laid-off staff who are
            willing to launch their own business.
